In this study, copolymer of poly (aniline-co-pyrrole) (P(ANI-co-Py)) was synthesized through copolymerization with (NH4)2S2O8 (APS) as oxidizing agent. Au nanoparticles (NPs) were deposited on P(ANI-co-Py) through the Au sol adsorption technique to obtain Au/P(ANI-co-Py) catalysts. For comparison, Au/PPy and Au/PANI were also prepared under the same procedure. The samples were characterized by SEM, TEM, XPS, N2 adsorption/desorption, XRD and FT-IR. Results imply that the P(ANI-co-Py) can be successfully prepared and can stabilize the small Au NPs with highly dispersed state. As expected, the Au/P(ANI-co-Py) catalysts, especially Au/P(5ANI-co-Py5), show efficient performance compared with Au/PANI and Au/PPy in 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) reduction. The outstanding catalytic activities of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) can be ascribed to well dispersed Au NPs, strong electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI), an appropriate adsorption of 4-NP and the negatively charged Au NPs surface. This work offers a facile method to provide conductive polymers supported Au catalysts with high catalytic performance and excellent reusability and clarifies their potential applications in industrial wastewater treatment. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Gold catalysts Conductive polymer support 4-NP reduction Copolymerization 1 Introduction Since the innovative study of Haruta and Hutchings for CO oxidation and acetylene hydrochlorination with gold catalysts in the 1980s [1,2], gold catalysis has drawn great scientific interests because of their noticeable low-temperature activities and high catalytic selectivity. After decades of extensive efforts, nanogold catalysts have attracted wide interest of numerous scientific researchers in many reactions, oxidative reactions such as CO oxidation reaction [3], water-gas-shift reaction [4], propylene epoxidation [5], aldehydes oxidative esterification [6], selective hydrogenation such as alkylene reduction [7], aromatic nitro-compounds (for example, nitrostyrene or nitrophenol) reduction [8–10], α, β-unsaturated aldehydes or ketones reduction [11], and also for the amine-alcohol cross-coupling reaction [12]. In order to obtain gold catalysts with high activities, deposition of Au on suitable support, such as metal oxide, activated carbon and special stabilizing ligand, to stabilize the nano gold with a highly dispersed state is indispensable [13–14]. Since the discovery of conductive polymers (CPs), great interest has been attracted due to their diverse applications in sensors, catalysis, electrochromism, electromagnetic shielding, and so on [15,16]. Among them, polyaniline (PANI) and polypyrrole (PPy) are considered as the most feasible materials for applications due to their high and adjustable electrical conductivity and environmental stabilization [17,18]. In recent years, combination of CPs with noble metals has become an increasing research subject [19]. Many studies have showed good catalytic performance for PANI or PPy supported Au catalysts. Shoba et al. reported the preparation of Au-PANI composite catalysts with good electrocatalytic performance in the oxidation of dibenzothiophene and 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene. The interaction between PANI and Au was confirmed through the electron transfer between nitrogen groups of PANI and Au [20]. Li et al. developed an effortless way to fabricate PS/PANI by Swelling-Diffusion-Interfacial-Polymerization Method. Electrostatic adsorption between gold sol and PANI was employed to prepare PS/PANI-Au catalysts. The composite catalysts exhibited admirable catalytic performance and excellent stability in 4-NP reduction with NaBH4 as reductant. The enhancement of catalytic activities was also attributed to the synergic effect or the interaction of PANI support and noble nano metals [21]. Peshoria et al. synthesized OMWCNT/PPy/Au composite catalysts by the pyrrole and HAuCl4 redox reaction. The PPy was to provide highly conductive electron tunneling channels and also to be the catalytic sites which adsorbed the methylene blue (MB) dyes and the reductant BH4 − [22]. In our previous works, both PANI and PPy were used as the Au NPs support. And catalytic activities in 4-NP reduction were enhanced due to the interaction between Au and support [23,24]. It has been reported that the copolymerization of aniline and pyrrole exhibits better physicochemical properties compared with individual PANI or PPy, which is favorable for various applications [25]. Liang et al. coated poly(aniline-co-pyrrole) on reduced graphene oxide surface and found that the copolymer composites exhibited higher electrochemical and thermal stability compared with individual ones, which was due to the synergistic effect in the composites [26]. Chaudhary et al. reported the poly(aniline-co-pyrrole) nanospheres preparation and evaluated their ammonia sensing behavior. Excellent sensing properties were obtained for poly(aniline-co-pyrrole), compared with homopolymers based sensors [27]. However, the use of P(ANI-co-Py) as the gold catalysts support has not been reported to date. As we all know, the catalytic abilities of Au are usually related to the size of Au NPs and the kind of supports [13,28]. The interaction between Au and support is important, by which the electron state of Au can be tailored and the stability of Au can be improved [29]. In our previous works, we found that the electrons transfer can be observed between Au and conductive polymer support, by which the catalytic performance including activity and stability was enhanced [23,24]. Therefore, it is reasonable to acquire better catalytic performance when P(ANI-co-Py) is used as the carrier of Au NPs. And how exactly is the catalytic behavior of Au/P(ANI-co-Py)? What is the catalytic mechanism when P(ANI-co-Py) is used as the catalyst carrier? Further studies are imperative to explore the above issues. Herein, P(ANI-co-Py) copolymers with different monomer ratio are prepared through copolymerization and used as the carrier of Au NPs. The objectives of this research are to investigate the catalytic performance of Au/P(ANI-co-Py) and to clarify its corresponding relations with the structure of catalysts, especially the interaction between Au and P(ANI-co-Py). The catalytic performance in simulated wastewater circumstances is also explored in this paper. This work can give guidance to design other polymer supported high stable Au catalysts and provide a potential application in the efficient treatment of wastewater from industries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and measurement techniques Aniline, pyrrole, 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), sodium borohydride (NaBH4), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36 wt%), HAuCl4•4H2O and polyvinyl alcohol, were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Corporation. Ammonium peroxydisulfate (APS) was obtained from Shanghai Zhanyun Chemical Reagent Corporation. All chemicals in this work were of reagent grade and used as received. The morphology and structure of P(ANI-co-Py) and Au/P(ANI-co-Py) catalysts were characterized by SEM (JEOL, JSM-7900F) and TEM (Tecnai G2 F30). FT-IR spectrometer (VERTEX70) was used to confirm the samples structure. The XRD patterns were investigated with Cu Kα radiation (Rigaku Dmax 2500) with step rate 10°/min. The size distribution of Au on P(ANI-co-Py) was determined by TEM images with evaluation of more than 200 Au particles. The actual loading content of Au in catalysts was obtained by ICP-AES (IRIS IIXSP). The BET surface area and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were investigated by a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The chemical states of N and Au in the catalyst were performed on an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, ESCALAB250) employing AlKα standard source (1486.6 eV). The catalysts were evacuated under 10−5 Pa in the fore chamber and then transferred to the analytical chamber under 10−8 Pa for analysis. All XPS spectra were obtained in constant analyzer energy mode (CAE) with a pass energy of 20 eV. The aperture diameter was 0.5 mm and the energy step size was 0.05 eV. The binding energy (BE) of C1s core level at 284.8 eV was used as the corrective standard. Shirley background subtraction was used in all XPS spectra and Gaussian fitting functions were employed for fitting peaks. For N 1 s XPS spectra, four peaks at 398.12, 398.92, 400.03, and 401.36 eV of the =N- (quinoid), -NH- (benzoid), = NH+ (cationic), and -NH+ (protonated) were added for fitting peaks. And for Au 4f XPS spectra, two standard BE peaks at 84.00 and 86.70 eV of Au 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 were added during fitting in a fixed area ratio at 4:3. 2.2 Preparation of P(ANI-co-Py) composites P(ANI-co-Py) composites were prepared via simultaneous copolymerization of aniline and pyrrole in hydrochloric acid as dopant with APS as oxidant at room temperature. Briefly, 10 mmol aniline and pyrrole monomer (nominal aniline to pyrrole molar ratio was designated as 9:1, 7:3, 5:5, 3:7 and 1:9, respectively) were injected into 50 mL HCl solution (1.2 M). To the above reaction mixture, 2.284 g APS was introduced slowly under stirring by dissolving it in 50 mL HCl solution (1.2 M). The copolymerization was proceeded without stirring for 6 h in dark. The resulting precipitates were washed and dried at 60 °C overnight. By varying the molar ratio of aniline to pyrrole (x:y), different copolymerized products were obtained and denoted as P(xANI-co-yPy). Individual polymerized products PANI and PPy were prepared with the same preparation process for comparison. 2.3 Preparation of Au/P(ANI-co-Py) catalysts The Au/P(ANI-co-Py) catalysts were synthesized via a gold sol adsorption method. The fresh gold sol was prepared before being used referred to our previous work [30]. 0.1 g P(ANI-co-Py) composites were mixed with 17 mL Au sol and stirred for a day to allow the adequate adsorption between Au NPs and P(ANI-co-Py). The resulting precipitates were washed and dried at 60 °C overnight. Au/PANI and Au/PPy were prepared with the same preparation process for comparison. The Au nominal content was 0.5 wt% for all catalysts in this paper. 2.4 Catalytic testing The catalytic 4-NP reduction was carried out with reducing agent NaBH4. Catalytic activity measurements were conducted by using 0.01 g catalyst with 5.5 ml 5.43 mmol/L 4-NP solution. Firstly, freshly prepared NaBH4 solution (0.17 g NaBH4 in 15 ml H2O) was mixed with 4-NP solution in a flask. Subsequently, the catalysts were added to the solution under stirring. At certain time intervals, 0.5 mL of the solution was removed from the flask, filtrated and diluted in 5 ml water in a quartz cuvette. UV–vis spectrophotometer (Carry 5000) was used to monitor the 4-NP concentration. The catalytic performance was calculated according to the equation: (1) L n C t C 0 = L n A t A 0 = − k t where At/A0 and Ct/C0 was the absorbance ratio at 400 nm of 4-NP and the concentration ratio at time t and 0. And k was the rate constant. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows the structure of copolymer P(ANI-co-Py), homopolymer PPy and PANI studied by FT-IR. Peaks at 1579 and 1496 cm−1 in PANI spectrum are attributed to the C = C stretching mode for quinone and benzene ring [23]. Characteristic bands at 1301, 1140 and 824 cm−1 belong to the CN stretching mode of the secondary aromatic amine, C = N stretching mode of dibasic aromatic amine (-N=quinoid=N-) and the CH out-of-plane in benzene ring, respectively. All peaks of PANI exist in the spectrum of P(9ANI-co-1Py) because of the relatively high content of aniline constitutional units in copolymers. In PPy, peaks at 1547, 1464, 1177, 1042 and 907 cm−1 are attributed to C = C and CC stretching of pyrrole ring, the vibration of CN bond, the in-plane and out-of-plane CH vibration of pyrrole ring, respectively [31]. With pyrrole units increasing in copolymers, the spectra of P(ANI-co-Py) are very close to that of PPy due to the neighboring pyrrole and aniline constitutional units in the copolymer [32]. The peaks at 907 and 1042 cm−1 shift obviously to higher wavenumbers (for example, 918 and 1049 cm−1 of P(5ANI-co-5Py)) in the spectra of P(ANI-co-Py) demonstrating the successful preparation of copolymers. Moreover, a peak at 1705 cm−1 is found for all P(ANI-co-Py) copolymers except for P(9ANI-co-1Py) with the highest mol ratio between aniline and pyrrole, which is assigned to the carbonyl C = O stretching due to the keto-enol tautomerism of -OH introduced on the ring by nucleophilic attack of H2O demonstrating the existence of adjoining pyrrole and aniline units in the copolymers [33]. Therefore, based on the above analysis, the structure of copolymer should have PANI units and PPy units in the polymer chain as shown in Fig. S1. Cl− anions was dopped into the growing P(ANI-co-Py) chain due to doping effect of HCl acid. Similar structure was also given by Bhaumik and coworkers [34–35]. The length of PANI sequence or PPy sequence could be adjusted by controlling the mol ratio between aniline and pyrrole monomers in the copolymerization. Fig. 2 provides the SEM images of homopolymer PPy, PANI and copolymers P(ANI-co-Py). Fig. 2c indicates a rod-like or fibrillar structure due to the intrinsic fibrillar growth of PANI. The morphology of P(9ANI-co-1Py) as shown in Fig. S2d is similar to that of PANI due to the high content of aniline in copolymer. However, with the decrease of mol ratio between aniline and pyrrole, the morphologies of P(ANI-co-Py) in Fig. S2 show spherical structures formed by agglomerated particles, gradually the same as that of PPy in Fig. 2a. It is well known that the π* interactions between pyrrole chains are strong and lead to the tendency to aggregate into spherical structures [36]. Therefore, with the change of mol ratio between aniline and pyrrole, the morphology changes because of the number changes of neighboring pyrrole and aniline constitutional units in the copolymers. Therefore, just like the results of FT-IR analysis, we confirm that the resulted composites are copolymers, not mixture of homopolymer PPy and PANI, because that the composite morphologies are not the mixture of spherical and fibrillar structures. The FT-IR spectra in Fig. 3 are belong to Au/PPy, Au/PANI and Au/P(ANI-co-Py). Compared with PANI in Fig. 1, the peaks of PANI at 1579, 1496, 1301, 1140, and 824 cm−1 shift to 1581, 1498, 1305, 1143, and 828 cm−1 in that of Au/PANI, respectively. And the characteristic bands of PPy at 1547, 1464, 1177, 1042, and 907 cm−1 also shift to high wavenumbers markedly at 1564, 1483, 1212, 1050, 927 cm−1 in that of Au/PPy. The shift of characteristic peaks in Au/PANI and Au/PPy implies the presence of interaction between Au NPs and polymer support [37]. Similar phenomena are observed in the spectra of P(ANI-co-Py) and the carbonyl C = O stretching at 1705 cm−1 shifts to 1716 cm−1 also confirming the interaction between Au NPs and P(ANI-co-Py). The X-ray diffraction patterns of Au/P(ANI-co-Py), Au/PPy and Au/PANI are shown in Fig. 4. Au/PANI shows small peaks at 2θ = 25.2, 20.5 and 14.9° indicating that the PANI with rod-like or fibrillar structure is a little crystalline [36]. And the broad peak at 2θ = 25.4° in Au/PPy confirms the amorphous nature of PPy [38]. For the Au/P(9ANI-co-1Py), the characteristic peaks are similar to that of Au/PANI due to the high aniline constitutional units in the copolymer. With the increase of pyrrole in the copolymerization process, the XRD patterns of Au/P(ANI-co-Py) turn to be similar to Au/PPy due to the insert of neighboring pyrrole in the polyaniline chain, which also indicate the successful preparation of P(ANI-co-Py). It should be pointed out that there are no gold diffraction peaks in all samples indicating the presence of highly dispersed Au NPs in the catalysts [7]. Fig. 5 shows the TEM images of Au/PPy, Au/P(ANI-co-Py) and Au/PANI. In Fig. 5a, after the loading of Au NPs, many dark dots with size in the range of 2∼6 nm can be observed on the spherical PPy surface (as shown in the inset image of Fig. 5a). It can be found in the HRTEM image of Au/PPy in Fig. 5a that the exposed lattice fringes with spacings 0.24 nm of Au (111) can be observed, which confirms Au loading through the gold sol deposition [39]. In TEM images of Au/P(ANI-co-Py) and Au/PANI illustrated in Fig. 5 and Fig. S3 and S4, Au NPs highly dispersed with almost the same size in range of 2∼6 nm on the P(ANI-co-Py) and PANI are observed, which is in line with the XRD analysis. The Au/P(ANI-co-Py) catalysts was tested in 4-NP reduction with excess NaBH4 at room temperature. UV–vis spectrophotometer was employed to confirm the reaction proceeding by recording the 4-NP absorbance changes with time passing. The 4-NP UV absorption is at 400 nm due to the 4-nitrophenolate formation with NaBH4 [40]. And the hydrogenation product 4-AP shows characteristic UV absorption at 300 nm. The reaction does not take place without catalysts. Whereas, it can react effectively with Au/P(ANI-co-Py), Au/PPy and Au/PANI as shown in Fig. 6 and Fig. S5. After catalysts addition, the reduction begins and the peak at 400 nm disappears and the new peak at 300 nm for product 4-AP is observed. It takes about 420 s for Au/PPy to completely convert 4-NP to 4-AP. And with the increase of aniline in copolymerization, it takes about 250 s, 240 s, 230 s, 360 s, 400 s and 480 s for Au/P(1ANI-co-9Py), Au/P(3ANI-co-7Py), Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py), Au/P(7ANI-co-3Py), Au/P(9ANI-co-1Py) and Au/PANI, respectively, indicating a trend of going down and then up. Thus, the catalytic performance shows a trend of going up and then down. Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) is the best among all the catalysts and takes about 230 s for the complete conversion. Therefore, compared with individual PANI or PPy, copolymerized support exhibits better catalytic properties. It has been reported that the copolymerization of aniline and pyrrole exhibit better physicochemical properties compared with individual PANI or PPy [25–27]. P(ANI-co-Py) with more aniline or pyrrole component usually has similar morphologies, structures and properties to PANI or PPy. More monomers applied in the copolymerization would bring about the samples with analogous characters to the corresponding homopolymer. And excellent properties were usually obtained with equimolar aniline and pyrrole in P(ANI-co-Py) [26,33,41-42], similar to our results for P(5ANI-co-5Py). According to the Eq. (1), due to the excess dosage of NaBH4 in the catalytic reduction, plots of ln(Ct/C0) against time obeyed first-order equation in Fig. 6b. The corresponding kinetic equations, rate constant k and correlation coefficient R2 were summarized in Table 1 . The k of Au/PPy is 0.00877 s − 1. And with the increase of aniline in copolymers, the k increases firstly and then decreases in agreement with the results shown in Fig. 6b. And the highest among them is 0.02156 s − 1 obtained from P(5ANI-co-5Py). Another evidence for the successful preparation of copolymers and their better properties can be obtained through the comparison of catalytic performance between Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) and the Au/PPy and Au/PANI mixture. Fig. S6 gives the catalytic performance of Au/PPy and Au/PANI with equal mass. It takes about 330 s for the complete conversion and the k is 0.01164 s − 1, which is only 54% of that of P(5ANI-co-5Py). As we all know, the catalytic performance of Au catalysts is usually related to the gold loading content, gold size, surface area and the chemical state of active sites. The loading of Au in all catalysts were characterized by ICP. As shown in Table 2 , all the loading content of Au is almost the same and is above 0.499%, very close to the theoretical loading content (0.5%), which means the effective loading of Au by sol adsorption method. [43] Combining with the results of XRD in Fig. 4 and TEM in Fig. 5, S3 and S4, we know that the Au NPs on all samples are in the same size range of 2∼6 nm with good dispersion. Therefore, the size, dispersion and the loading content of Au of all catalysts are the same and are not regarded as the primary reason for the remarkable catalytic activities of Au/P(ANI-co-Py). Fig. S7 shows the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of PPy, P(ANI-co-Py) and PANI. All samples show type IV characteristics, indicating the presence of mesoporous materials. It can be seen that the PANI, P(9ANI-co-1Py) and P(7ANI-co-3Py) exhibit the relatively high N2 adsorptions in all samples, demonstrating the high pore volume (0.194, 0.214 and 0.216 cm3/g, respectively). The textural properties in Table 2 of P(5ANI-co-5Py) were 26.51 cm2/g (BET surface area), 0.102 cm3/g (pore volume) and 21.49 nm (mean pore diameter). All the above properties of P(5ANI-co-5Py) are not the highest and are between that of PANI and PPy. Fig. S8a shows the UV–vis spectra of 4-NP reduction with P(5ANI-co-5Py). One can see that without loading of Au, the support shows no catalytic activities in the reaction. There are no peaks at 300 nm indicating that Au NPs are the active sites in catalytic 4-NP reduction. The absorbance changes in Fig. S8a are attributed to the adsorption balance of 4-NP [24]. Similar results are observed in Fig. S8b when the other supports are used. We calculated the differences between the maximum and minimum values (Δ absorbance) to estimate the adsorption ability of support for 4-NP. As shown in Fig. S8c, the Δ absorbance basically appears an increasing tendency with the increase of surface areas. It can be noted that P(5ANI-co-5Py) with high catalytic activities after Au loading do not show the high adsorption ability. As we all know, high surface areas usually represent good adsorption capacity and lead to the increase of catalytic activities. But too high substrate adsorption ability means the hard desorption after the reaction, which is certainly harmful for the catalytic reaction. Therefore, P(5ANI-co-5Py) with a moderate surface area and an appropriate adsorption capacity possesses the highest catalytic activities after Au loading. The reusability of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) has been investigated and reused for ten times at the same catalytic test conditions. During each cycle, the catalyst was separated and washed, then dried before used in the next circle. It should be noted that the amount of catalyst used in the reaction is little and the density of conductive polymer is small, so it is hard for the catalyst's separation. In order to characterize the recyclability of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) as accurate as possible, the catalyst is compensated to 0.01 g for each cycle (Table S1). As shown in Fig. 7, after ten cycles, the conversion of 4-NP is still above 98%, which illustrates the outstanding catalytic stability of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py). Au NPs still maintain highly dispersed state and no obvious agglomeration is observed in Fig. 7b and Fig. S9. The size of Au on P(5ANI-co-5Py) is 2∼6 nm in diameter as shown in Fig. 7c. Compared with Fig. 5d, the size distribution and morphology of Au NPs have no change, which also confirms the excellent catalytic stability of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py). As we all know, metal-support interaction (MSI), including strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) and electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI), plays an important role in catalytic performance [44,45]. Au nanoparticles reduced by NaBH4 with PVA as protecting agent usually are in metallic state [30,46]. Fig. 8 provides the Au 4f core level XPS spectra of Au/PPy, Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) and Au/PANI. For Au/PPy, the peaks centered at 84.00 and 87.65 eV are attributed to Au 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 spin-orbit splitting of metallic gold (Au0), respectively. And with the increase of aniline in the copolymerization, a shift at 4f7/2 signal is observed to low binding energy at 83.94, 83.95, 83.78, 83.76, 83.8 and 83.77 eV for Au/P(1ANI-co-9Py), Au/P(3ANI-co-7Py), Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py), Au/P(7ANI-co-3Py), Au/P(9ANI-co-1Py) and Au/PANI (Fig. 8, S10 and Table S2), which means the metallic Au surface is negatively charged. And compared with Au/PPy, Au/P(1ANI-co-9Py) and Au/P(3ANI-co-7Py), the Au 4f7/2 signal shift of Au/P(ANI-co-Py) with higher aniline unite is more obvious, which indicates the relatively stronger EMSI in Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py), Au/P(7ANI-co-3Py), Au/P(9ANI-co-1Py) and Au/PANI. The strong EMSI is attributed to the interaction between Au and conjugated polymers support and can effectively stabilize Au NPs to endow the catalyst with excellent catalytic stability [47]. Similar result was obtained by Liu et al. in Au@TiO2-x/ZnO catalysts and found that the EMSI between Au metal and TiO2-x support is vital for designing efficient Au catalysts with good stability [48]. There are some works noted the interaction between Au and conductive polymers. For example, Dai and coworkers studied the Au/TiO2-PANI ternary composite catalysts and found PANI could play as electron transmitter and favor the negatively charged Auδ− (0 < δ < 1) formation, which showed promoted effect in CO oxidation [49]. The electron transferred from PANI to the metallic gold surface and made the Au charged negatively [30]. Getting or losing electrons would certainly influence the molecular structure of conductive polymers due to their special redox properties. Therefore, with the electron transfer between support and Au, the oxidation or the reducing state of support would be changed [23,50]. As shown in Fig. S11, the respective N 1 s core-level spectra of P(5ANI-co-5Py) and Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) show no obvious differences with a peak centered at 399.9 eV due to the low loading amount of Au. The curve fitted N 1 s XPS for both P(5ANI-co-5Py) and Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) show four peaks of the =N-, -NH-, = NH+ and -NH+. Quantification and identification of N species over P(5ANI-co-5Py) and Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) for N 1 s XPS data were summarized in Table S3. The total oxidation state of N species (=N- and = NH+) is 65.93% for Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py), which is a little higher than that for P(5ANI-co-5Py) (61.82%). It means that after loading of Au, P(5ANI-co-5Py) support loses electrons and is oxidized slightly. Therefore, combining with the Au XPS spectra in Fig. 8, we confirm the transfer of electron between Au and copolymer support. And the electron transfer indicates the relatively stronger EMSI in Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py), which endows the catalyst with excellent catalytic stability. Although comparative Au 4f7/2 signal shifts are found in Fig. 8 and S10 for Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py), Au/P(7ANI-co-3Py), Au/P(9ANI-co-1Py) and Au/PANI, Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) gains the best catalytic performance due to its appropriate adsorption capacity discussed above. The negatively charged Au favors the active Au-H intermediates formation and the 4-NP molecules activation, which favors the catalytic performance improvement [23,51]. A widely accepted catalytic mechanism with three major stages is adopted (Scheme 1 ) [40,52]. At first, the electron donor BH4 − and 4-NP (deprotonated) are reversibly adsorbed on Au/P(ANI-co-Py) surface. And synchronously Au-H active sites are produced due to the BH4 − dissociation. Then electrons and Au-H species are transferred to the adsorbed 4-NP and lead to the reduction of -NO2. At last, 4-AP is desorbed from the catalyst surface. Therefore, the superior catalytic performance of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) could be summarized to the following respects: (i) Au NPs with small and uniform size can offer more active Au-H sites; (ii) the support with a moderate surface area and an appropriate adsorption capacity favors the adsorption of 4-NP and the desorption after the reaction; (iii) the support can provide good protection for Au NPs through the strong EMSI and endows the catalyst with excellent catalytic stability; (iv) the negatively charged Au favors the active Au-H species formation and 4-NP molecules activation because that it can easily adsorb 4-NP with a relatively more positive charge than the product 4-AP [53]. The catalytic activity of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) is compared with various Au-based catalysts reported in the literature. To best compare the reported results, k’ are calculated and are shown in Table 3 . The supports of Au NPs cover various materials, such as inorganic materials Al2O3 [54], CeO2 and montmorillonite [55], carbon materials [56], organic polymer materials carboxymethyl cellulose-chitosan [57] and vinyl benzyl chloride-co-divinylbenzene (VBC-co-DVB) copolymers [58]. In this paper, in order to expediently study the interaction of Au and P(ANI-co-Py), the size of Au NPs was controlled as the same by the gold sol method. As shown in Table 3, compared with Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py), the catalytic performance of Au/CMCCH, Au/CMCCHZY and Au@HEP was lower due to the big size of Au NPs. Although the size of Au in Au/Al2O3, Au-Mt/CeO2 and Au/CB is comparative or even smaller compared with Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py), the k’ of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) outclasses of all others. Therefore, based on our results and the above comparison, we believe that the well dispersed small Au NPs, strong EMSI, the appropriate adsorption of 4-NP and the negatively charged Au NPs surface favor the improvement of the catalytic performance of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py). 4-NP is a toxic contaminant in wastewater. Its reduction product 4-AP is less toxic, more biodegradable and is a vital intermediate for antipyretic drugs production [59]. Considering practical application for catalysts in wastewater treatment, we studied the catalytic performance of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) in the presence of different inorganic salt or organics to imitate the wastewater circumstances. As illustrated in Fig. 9 a, Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) shows good adaptability with different concentration of NaNO3. When the concentration of NaNO3 is less than or equal to 0.5 mol/L, the catalytic reduction rate increases with the increase of NaNO3 concentration. However, it decreases with 1 mol/L NaNO3. As one kind of electrolytes, in one aspect, NaNO3 can facilitate the charge migration and increase the catalytic rate. In another, NaNO3 might adsorb on the surface of catalyst and cover the active sites, resulting in catalyst passivation. It should be noted that at 1 mol/L NaNO3 (686 time of 4-NP concentration), the reaction rate is 0.02245 s − 1, which is still comparable or even higher than the reaction without NaNO3. In Fig. 9b, except for glucose and Na3PO4, which display the negative effect in the reaction, Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) shows good adaptability at all other species such as NaCl, Na2SO4, KCl and urea (CH4N2O). Therefore, we believe that Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) is the promising catalyst in treatment of 4-NP in wastewater. 3 Conclusions We have prepared P(ANI-co-Py) with different molar ratio of aniline and pyrrole by copolymerization with HCl as dopant and APS as oxidant. Highly dispersed Au NPs were loaded on P(ANI-co-Py) through adsorption. Combined with the results of FT-IR, XRD, TEM and SEM, we confirm the successful preparation of P(ANI-co-Py) copolymer and the successful loading of Au NPs highly dispersed on P(ANI-co-Py) (2∼6 nm). Through the comparison of catalytic performance of Au/ P(ANI-co-Py), Au/PANI and Au/PPy, we find Au NPs loaded on copolymer support possess better catalytic activities in 4-NP reduction and Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) is the best. Detailed investigations suggest that the superior catalytic performance of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) could be attributed to the well dispersed Au NPs, strong EMSI, an appropriate adsorption of 4-NP and the negatively charged Au NPs surface. And all the above four aspects benefit from special copolymerized support, which stabilize Au NPs to maintain the dispersion and size of Au, transfer electron to Au by EMSI and endow the catalyst with an appropriate adsorption of 4-NP. In view of the remarkable catalytic performance and excellent reusability, Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) are recognized as a promising catalyst in industrial wastewater treatment, and this paper offers a new strategy to design high stable Au catalysts with excellent catalytic activities. coredata.dc:description: In this study, copolymer of poly (aniline-co-pyrrole) (P(ANI-co-Py)) was synthesized through copolymerization with (NH4)2S2O8 (APS) as oxidizing agent. Au nanoparticles (NPs) were deposited on P(ANI-co-Py) through the Au sol adsorption technique to obtain Au/P(ANI-co-Py) catalysts. For comparison, Au/PPy and Au/PANI were also prepared under the same procedure. The samples were characterized by SEM, TEM, XPS, N2 adsorption/desorption, XRD and FT-IR. Results imply that the P(ANI-co-Py) can be successfully prepared and can stabilize the small Au NPs with highly dispersed state. As expected, the Au/P(ANI-co-Py) catalysts, especially Au/P(5ANI-co-Py5), show efficient performance compared with Au/PANI and Au/PPy in 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) reduction. The outstanding catalytic activities of Au/P(5ANI-co-5Py) can be ascribed to well dispersed Au NPs, strong electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI), an appropriate adsorption of 4-NP and the negatively charged Au NPs surface. This work offers a facile method to provide conductive polymers supported Au catalysts with high catalytic performance and excellent reusability and clarifies their potential applications in industrial wastewater treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Gold nanoparticles supported on poly (aniline-co-pyrrole) as the efficient catalysts for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol
